awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Biodegradable trimmings and embellishments for the apparel industry
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of sustainable and customizable trimmings for the apparel industry that are biodegradable to reduce the negative environmental effects in landfills. Currently, the creation of trimmings and embellishments such as buttons and sequins for the fashion industry is done using petroleum-based plastics. These embellishments are not biodegradable, making up for a sizable portion of the 14 million tons of waste produced annually by the apparel industry. The proposed technology uses plant-based plastics and small order minimums to partner with designers that are looking for customizable and biodegradable alternatives. Plant-based plastics are expected to degrade naturally in the environment once placed in the landfill at a minimal environmental cost. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of biodegradable and industrially compostable trimmings and embellishments for the apparel industry. The proposed trimmings will be made from sustainable plant-based biodegradable polymer with a variety of fashion features such as brightness, texture, and shape.  In addition, using computer numerical control (CNC) technology such as computer-aided design, laser cutting, and 3D printing, these products may be created with minimal waste without sacrificing quality. Also, the proposed technology will make use of natural pigments such as hemp, coffee, and algae, which may contribute to sustainability. Unlike trimmings and embellishments made from petroleum-based plastics, these products are expected to cause little harm to the environment when eventually discarded. While chemical dyes commonly found in plastic trimmings and embellishments have been found to be harmful to the environment, the proposed natural pigments are not expected to cause damage during the biodegradation process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Biodegradable trimmings and embellishments for the apparel industry

The objective for this project was to determine whether there was a market that would be interested in sustainable trimmings and sequins that could scale for a larger demographic. The target market was identified as three channels including manufacturers who can make the sequins from pellets and then sell to brands via trade shows, larger brands who want to want to buy directly from us or have us work with their manufacturers, and small designers whose main focus is customized sustainable trimmings and want to create custom work in small quantities.

The major activities that led to this development included interviewing the manufacturers who have shown interest in the patent, interviewing material sourcing directors at large and small companies, and developing a capsule collection with smaller designers such as Diana Broussard and Nikolaj Storm as part of a scope of work project. The PI attended multiple trade shows in New York and London to meet with potential competitors and buyers of the product to conduct interviews and observational research.

A significant outcome from this project included a collaboration with the Texas Science and Natural History Museum for the exhibit titled, Particles of Color; Where Science Meets Fashion. This exhibit features 50 fashion, art, and jewelry objects showcasing the sustainable sequins in various mediums and will be on display to the public through the summer of 2025. Another development included creating a new lab class at the University of Texas at Austin focused on sustainable fashion materials where students learned how to laser cut, 3d print, mix colors and heat press sheets to make the sequins. 

www.particlesofcolor.com

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2024
Modified by: Jessica Ciarla
